 Don't worry about it. A nuke plant loosing a few fuel rods is not that uncommon. They almost always find them later, usually misbundled. Not too long ago the nuke plant not far from my house lost quite a few rods. Apparentlt the standard tracking protocalls utilized by US nuke plants have some flaws (namely that they are WAY over complicated and a small error anywhere in the process can make fuel rods "disapear"). They do an inventory, actually open the containers and count material (instead of just reying on the bar code on the container) and they find the missing rods. At the plant near me, they actually found MORE rods than were missing. THis is what happens when you have guidlines set by commitee.
 
 Nuke power is safe, clean and efficient. There can not be another 3 mile island in the us (or most of the rest of the world). Now we have improved instrumentation and better secondary systems, included automated shut down systems. The accident at 3 mile island was caused by a faulty pressure valve. You would NEVER find a crucial component like that without a backup in a currently operating nuclear plant.

 The one by me is Wolf Creek (in kansas). I think that some of the big issues w/ nuclear power plants is that every little burp or problem at the plant turns into a huge deal.
 
 Last year, our local paper carried news about a safety system failure at wolf creek. They questioned the safety of nuclear power, and made a big deal about how important the sfety systems at a nuke power plant,m and how we were all in danger if they failed.
 
 The "safety system failure" was a bad fire alarm door switch (you know the doors that say "alarm will sound"). It was found during a safety inspection, and as per NRC regulations, the pertinent paperwork was done. In most places it never would have been found, and if it was, a new $4 switch would have been installed. No big deal. But since it was at the nuclear plant, they turned it onto some kind of big fiasco. According to the NRC (nuclear regulatory comission) there are 0.10 serious problems per nuclear plant per year. Even their definition of "serios problem" errs pretty heavily on the side of safety. A pressure relief valve failing today still counts as a "Serios proble" though there is now triple redundancy on these, special sensors installed so the people in the control room know EXACTLY what is goin on with them, plus TWO manual systems in case all FOUR of the primary systems fail. Most plants also have systems in place so any time anything unusual happens (like a pressure valve popping) somebody is sent to visually inspect the unit (When possible) until the situation is green boarded (declared over).

 Unfortunately, I spoke too soon about the emergency shutdown. I was referring to scramming by injecting moderator poison, which is one of the scram systems in CANDU-style heavy water reactors. American nuclear plants use various different designs, so it's hard to speak for all of them, but they have at least a system that rapidly inserts the control and safety rods into the reactor. Those things are heavy, so terrorists are going to have one hell of a time getting them out, especially since most plants have the control rods held up by an electromagnetic field generated by the reactor itself, so once it's shut off there's nothing to hold the rods up.
